subject: Re: Test genes, test infected rates, and test-resistant managers
msgSnippet: ... Hi Joe, Very interesting points. I believe that a lot of people in the testing field and industry have been waiting for that big event that will change
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "ponczak" <ponczak@...> wrote:

> I may be reaching here, but the question in my mind revolves around the
> 'event' that will change people's mind. The plublicized class action
> lawsuit against a software company because of a major defect (security,
> logic, whatever) will open the floodgates especially since membership in
> the ABA Law Group has experienced exponential growth. Lawyers have to
> do something, right :)

Hi Joe,

Very interesting points.

I believe that a lot of people in the testing field and industry have
been waiting for that big event that will change testing
attitudes/practices/laws/etc.

I am very surprised it hasn't happened yet and I am no longer holding
my breath waiting for it :-).

Your other point about risk/reward is also very good. There are too
many examples of software companies that are very successful despite
very buggy code.

> You started an interesting thread, and I look forward to the other
> responses.

I am surprised at the very few responses we go so far. I guess
everyone here has the T1 gene in spades. There has been much more
discussion on this very same topic on my Artima blog. Perhaps you can
check that out and post your opinion there:

http://www.artima.com/weblogs/viewpost.jsp?thread=192781


Alberto

Try http://www.junitfactory.com
You send it Java code and get
back JUnit tests. 100% free.
